we oversee manufacturing of hemp consumables, meaning things like food and lotions containing hemp made in the state of connecticut. we also work to ensure lab testing of products is thorough in order to ensure public health and safety.

we had a great time today at the connecticut 2020 hemp conference and trade show talking with businesses owners about their experiences. at dcp, we have a small, but important part of ct’s hemp pilot program.

remember, utility companies in connecticut will never demand immediate payment over the phone.

thank you to everyone who joined us to warn consumers about utility scams this winter. if you get a call demanding immediate payment: hang up the phone never pay anyone in an untraceable form of payment report the scam to your utility company
unfortunately scammers follow the headlines and take advantage of consumers good nature, and desire to stay healthy.

scam artists follow headlines and prey on your desire to stay healthy - don't fall for it. get more information in today's scam alert -->
if you get an email, text, or call advertising a miracle cure, opportunity to donate, or an "investment opportunity" - don't open it. if it has to with coronavirus, it's likely a scam.

still making last minute plans for valentinesday? check out that drawer of gift cards you received over the holidays. if you don't use them as soon as you can - you might miss out all together. get the story from  --->

remember these signs it’s a scam: they’re too good to be true, they want to talk “offline”, they talk almost too much about trust, they say i love you right away, they make you feel guilty if you don’t support them financially, they won’t meet in person

happy valentine's day from all of us at dcp. it can be hard to avoid talk about love, and relationships today - but, don't let that lower your guard, and allow you to fall victim to a scam, especially online.

we want to make sure consumers have the opportunity to use the cards they receive - instead of finding out months, or even years later that a business they intended to use it at has closed. find more tips in today's release -->

if you have a gift card you received over the holiday season, and you haven't used it yet - use it immediately, especially if it's for a restaurant. dcp has seen a small increase in complaints about restaurant gift cards in the past few years.
he also reminded all of us not only to be careful when we get unsolicited phone calls, but also not to click on any suspicious links.

unfortunately, it’s not expensive to be a scam artist. consumers need to be careful, and think twice before giving anyone personal or financial information.
never give money to anyone you don’t know or trust, file your taxes early, if you use one, research your tax preparer

we process over 200 different credential types here at dcp, and one is medical marijuana dispensary facilitates. we like to make it a priority to visit businesses we regulate, and we had a great tour and discussion today at thames valley relief. thanks for having us!
our program is the first in the country that is based on a true medical model that doesn’t break the relationship between a patient, physician, and pharmacists.
one metric we’re incredibly proud of is the growth of medical professionals that certify patients for the program and have faith in this program as an alternative for their patients.
this morning we’re at the eastern ct chamber if commerce this morning talking about the state of medical marijuana in our state.
thank you for having us! it was a great evening. congratulations to our new licensees!
we want to thank the residents for organizing, and working so hard to make sure this issue was brought to light.

imposter scams were the top scam reported to the  in 2019, and victims reported paying with a gift card most frequently. get their update here: https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/2020/01/top-frauds-2019?utm_source=govdelivery consumercomplaints

if you plan to buy a brand new tv, be sure to position it on a sturdy, low base when you get it home. push the tv as far back on the stand and as close to the wall as possible. get more information about furniture safety, and how to anchor your tv at --> https://www.anchorit.gov/how-to-anchor-it/

weeks leading up to the super bowl are some of the most popular to purchase new tvs. today’s flat screen tvs are lighter and more balanced than the older, heavier models. but, you should still take precautions to keep your family safe.

the ftc’s latest case charging a company with operating a pyramid scheme concerns “success by health” (sbh), a venture that the ftc alleges has bilked consumers who joined its sales network as “affiliates” out of more than $7 million. --->
that means you’ve heard warnings about illegal pyramid schemes that masquerade as legitimate multi-level marketing (mlm) businesses and promise life-changing income, but take your money instead.
consumeralert via the : earn unlimited income! quit your job! change your life! do we have your attention? good! are you rolling your eyes? even better.

in 2019, 82% of those who were eligible to renew online did, and increase from just 65% in 2015. learn more in today's release ---> https://portal.ct.gov/dcp/news-releases-from-the-department-of-consumer-protection/2020-news-releases/online-credential-renewals-increase-at-department-of-consumer-protection

online renewal of credentials at dcp is on the rise. dcp has continued to expand online credentialing, renewal, and reinstatement services in order to ensure businesses can comply with state requirements as efficiently as possible.

as always, thanks for having us, and don’t forget that if a health club closes and you have already paid for your membership, you can apply to our health club guaranty fund —> https://portal.ct.gov/dcp/common-elements/consumer-facts-and-contacts/health-club-guaranty-fund

always check the cancellation policy, and inquire about any additional add on fees before you sign a contract. plan to stop by a gym before you commit. that way, you can get a sense of what they have available at the times you’ll be working out. newyearsresolution

our drug control director, rod marriott, talked with  about what we've accomplished here as we combat the opioid crisis, and what work we still have to do. check out the video here --> https://surescripts.com/news-center/intelligence-in-action/opioids/changing-the-script-on-the-opioid-crisis/

dcp's drug control division regulates pharmaceuticals in the state, and oversees programs like the prescription monitoring program, and the drug drop box program. they also oversaw the implementation of electronic prescribing of controlled substances.

if you get a robo call, without a person on the other end, trying to sell you something, or offering you something for free, hang up - and don't press any buttons. read about a company the  caught offering free cruises, with a catch ---> https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/2020/01/free-cruise-try-illegal-robocall-upsell?utm_source=govdelivery

some not-so-honest outfits may try to confuse you into thinking they’re from the government and that you need to pay for certain documents to operate your business. get more information about a scam that shows up this time of year from the ​ ---> https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/blogs/business-blog/2020/01/certifiably-shady?utm_source=govdelivery

scamalert: certificates of existence, status, or good standing – sounds like an existential crisis, right? instead of a philosophical commentary on the meaning of life, the certificates in question refer to business documentation from your state or local government.
shady glen has been cooperative, and supportive in getting this food off of the shelves. foodsafety
the ice cream may contain soy, a common allergen that can cause serious or life-threatening reactions to those who have an allergy and consume the product.

foodsafetyadvisory: our food and standards division is advising those who may have an allergy to soy not to consume cookies and cream ice cream (one half gallon containers) produced by shady glen dairy bar. get more details in today's release --> https://portal.ct.gov/dcp/news-releases-from-the-department-of-consumer-protection/2019-news-releases/food-safety-advisory

for example, today's date, 1/3/20, could be easily modified by a scammer to be "1/3/2019" or "1/3/2018" without crossing out anything. that could leave you open to fraud when you sign checks or contracts, and even make it seem like you agreed to payments that you didn't.
avoid fraud by writing "2020" instead of just "20". read about why from  -->

unwanted calls are one of the number one complaint areas nationally. in addition to signing up for the do not call list: don’t answer calls from numbers you don’t recognize check with your phone company about call blocking or screening services they have
do your homework check references don’t fall victim to pressure tactics, and verify a credential by visiting http://www.elicense.ct.gov

there’s a difference between a registration and a license. a license is received after demonstrating knowledge or competence in an area in some way. a registration typically doesn’t require training, but there are often protections for consumers using registered professionals.
dcp does more than you might realize. we take, and resolve complaints, but we also license over 200 different professions, regulate food and standards, gaming, pharmaceuticals, and liquor.
starting now! we’re starting by talking about what we do here at the department of consumer protection, and how we can support consumers.

if you get one of these calls, hang up, take a deep breath, and call the person who is supposedly in trouble directly.

our deputy commissioner just warned the  audience about grandparent scams. grandparents and other family members get scam calls saying a family member is in trouble, and the only way to fix it is wiring money.

set. mark solomon from the  shared that more and more, scammers can find ways to look legitimate to fool us via email, online, and over the phone - so it’s more important for us to be suspicious and careful. fraudwatch

worried about stolen data? here’s how you can reduce the impact on your organization, your employees, and your customers: make a plan to respond to security incidents. learn more: https://go.usa.gov/xvtjs charityfraudout2019 charityfraudout

many data compromises happen the old-fashioned way—through lost or stolen paper documents. often, the best defense is a locked door or an alert employee. tips on physical security: https://go.usa.gov/xvtdp charityfraudout2019 charityfraudout

organizations keep sensitive information in their files that identifies clients, donors, or employees. if sensitive data falls into the wrong hands, it can lead to identity theft. a sound data security plan is built on 5 key principles: https://go.usa.gov/xvtzr charityfraudout
